title: And the Land Lay Still

This was Scotland in 1950: land of 250 pits and 80,000 colliers, 100,000 farmworkers and four universities; land of  Singer sewing machines in Clydebank, the  Saxone Shoe Company in Kilmarnock, Cox Brothers jute mills in Dundee and the North British Locomotive Company in Springburn, every town and city and every part of  every city with its own industries and hard-won skills; land of  textiles and paper, hydraulic pumps and valves, carpets and linoleum and twenty-eight shipyards employing 60,000 workers on the Clyde.

title: And the Land Lay Still

author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: The aggregate of these several falls, therefore, 174 feet, in so large a river as the Clyde, especially when swollen by heavy rains, must excitestrong emotions of awe and sublimity.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: The falls of the Clyde, are in the immediate vicinityof New Lanark, the very spot, where Robert Owen'spolitical and social millenium first dawned ; and fromwhence it shot its rays across the Atlantic, to NewHarmony, where its atheistical tendencies have beenfully developed, under the auspices of the youngerMr. Owen, and the notorious Fanny Wright.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: The Falls of the Clyde are thirty-two miles west ofEdinburgh, and nearly the same distance east of Glasgow.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: It lies at the head of navigation, on the Clyde, which passes through it, nearlyfrom east to west, on its way to the Irish Channel.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Thereis another rock, similar to this, of much greater circumference, but not so steep, nor quite so high, at themouth of the Clyde.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: And here, from sea to sea, run the best Scottishroads and highwavs, above all, that ancient water thoroughfare, theForth and Clyde canal ; and, lastly, making the plentiful moreabundant, the great new railway, direct from Glasgow to Edinburgh,and from each city throwing out branches and ramifying over thecountry.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: The counties which cluster around the Forth andClyde,—viz.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: But then, also, vessels of from 100to 200 tons burthen can ply upon it ; for, at high water, theaverage depth is from eight to nine feet.* In Ireland, all thecanals branch out from one place,—Dublin ; while in Scotland,se\eral distinct canals intersect the country in various places, moreparticularly two : first, this one between the Forth and the Clyde;

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: Not far from ihe west end of the city, I visited that part ofGlasgow called Port-Dundas, where an arm of the great canalwhich unites the Clyde and the Forth passes.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: The authorities possess sufficient power and influence to prevent the traffic of steamboatson the Clyde, and the travelling of coaches, on Sundays ; and surely, if thei eexists any necessity for the prohibition of those comparatively rational andharmless sources of recreation, it is still more indispensable that the moralsof the youth of Glasgow should be protected from the contamination to whichthey are liable from frequenting public-houses on the Sabbath.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: In 1842, the number ofriver steamboats plying upon the Clyde had reached its climax ;but since then the number has been reduced through the victoriouscompetition of railway conveyance.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: In 1835,there were no fewer than 67 steamers entering and leaving theClyde.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: than twelve steamboats plied upon the Clyde before the fish inthe Thames were disturbed by a single paddle-wheel.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: Henry Bell was the first who launched a steamer on the waters ofthe Clyde, and the Clyde was the first river in the old hemispherethat bore a steamer.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: Henry Bell was the first who launched a steamer on the waters ofthe Clyde, and the Clyde was the first river in the old hemispherethat bore a steamer.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: It guards the outletof the waters of Loch Lomond, which here flow into the Clyde.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: By the light of the island of Pladda we reach the still waters ofthe Frith of Clyde, and by aid of the light on Cambray the innerand narrower parts of its channel, which is also illuminated bythe lights of Inoland and Greenock.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: We steered NNE.; for this north-north-east, or north-east, isthe direction in which one coming from the west approaches theinterior of Scotland, whether it be by the Frith of Clyde toGreenock and Glasgow, or by Loch Fine to Inverary ; or byLoch Linnhe towards Fort-William.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: At the distance of amile, or a mile and a half, as you ascend the Clyde,commences a high ledge of the same kindof rock,stretching with a bold front along the bank of theriver for a considerable distance, and then retiringtowards the mountains in the back-ground.

title: Great Britain, France and Belgium: a short tour in 1835
author: Humphrey, Heman
snippet: Of these last, the castle of Dunbarton, on the Clyde,a few miles below Greenock, is the most remarkable.
